title: airport sinage id
content:
hi guys,

first, best wishes for 2009 everyone

i'm doing a litl work on type used in public places  
i found a nice photo post on airport signage, but i can't really recognize some of them

aren't most of them frutiger?

here's the link:

[http://www.designworkplan.com/design/airport-signage-photo-inspiration.htm](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019170612/http:/www.designworkplan.com/design/airport-signage-photo-inspiration.htm "http://www.designworkplan.com/design/airport-signage-photo-inspiration.htm")
author: omar

comments.content: Yes, most of them seem to be Frutiger, though many of the German signs are in Univers/ Helvetica nd one in Portland is Futura. In signage, sans-serif rules!

Hi Omar, thanks for linking to my article.

Most typefaces used for airport signage is indeed **Frutiger** , first designed for Charles de Gaulle, Paris. Other typefaces that can be used for airport signage are eg. **FF Info** (Spiekermann), **FF DIN** (Albert Jan Pool), **FF Transit** (MetaDesign). I have seen uses of Helvetica and Gill Sans, although I find those typefaces not very suitable for airport signage. Good luck.
If I remember correctly, just like Frutiger, FF Info was designed especially for airport signage (Düsseldorf airport).

One I like, especially the little figures, from Katowice airport in Poland.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20131019170612im_/http:/typophile.com/files/P9120039_3962.jpg)

Seattle is Myriad, and it's too bold, like most signage type, especially when reversed out of dark.  
Katowice is FF Info. And i like the regular weight better than the bold above.
